text:
Stakeholder Profile

Choose one stakeholder to think about in more depth. Then begin making your stakeholder profile in the sketch box below.

1. Create a title for your sketch (for example, "Stakeholder Profile of [Insert Name]")

2. of at least three things that are important to this stakeholder. Reflect on their values, beliefs, interests, motivations, and anything else you may know about them. Create one image (from google images) and one text box for each of these important things and add them to the sketch box.

3. Think of at least three ways that this stakeholder uses water or ways they could conserve water. Create one image (from google images) and one text box for each of these ideas and add them the sketch box.

4. Look over your images and re-read your text boxes. Why is water conservation important to this stakeholder? What does this stakeholder need? Add a text box to your sketch to answer these questions. ("Water conservation is important to [name] because [reason]. [Name] could use a design solution that [has/is/does....]")

Example: Water conservation is important to Principal Jones because she pays for the school's water and wants to save money. Principal Jones needs a design solution that is easy to understand for students of all ages so that all the students save a little water and overall Principal Jones can make the school save a lot of water.

Examining Assumptions

You probably had to make some assumptions to create this stakeholder profile. In the text box below, note at least two assumptions you made and how you might clarify these assumptions.

Examples:

  • I think Ms. Jones runs the dishwasher in her house every day but I'm not sure because I don't live in her house. She might not even have a dishwasher! I could ask her if she has a dishwasher and how many times she uses it in a week.
  • I think most 8th graders do not turn off the tap when they brush their teeth but I'm not sure. I always turn off the tap because I learned to do this in an assembly last year but I know it is hard to remember so I assume most of the students don't do it. I could ask 8th graders about this but they might say they turn off the water when most times the don't. Maybe if I could ask them anonymously then they might feel comfortable being honest about whether they turn off the water or not.

Water Conservation Design Solutions in Your Area

Use the links below to read about at least two water conservation design solutions in your area. (You might like to open all the links, skim the articles, and then choose the two that are most interesting to you.) For each solution you read about, use the chart below to make notes. Note information about what the water conservation solution is and whether or not you think this is a good solution for your stakeholders.

tiles.title: Notes: Water Conservation Solutions in My Community

attributes.name: What is the water conservation solution?
Will this solution work for my stakeholders? Why or why not?
